PHYSICS
0625/52
Paper 5 Practical Test
February/March 2025
1 hour 15 minutes
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[917, 273, 967, 286]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 346, 395, 362]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 384, 700, 399]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 419, 222, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 758, 466]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 479, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 322, 544]]<|/det|> - You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 579, 560]]<|/det|> - You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 589, 214, 602]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 388, 620]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 40. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 620, 730, 635]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[725, 649, 890, 665]]<|/det|> For Examiner's Use <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[708, 667, 908, 844]]<|/det|>

Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 869, 611, 885]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 1 In this experiment, you will investigate the behaviour of a spring and use it to determine the mass of an object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 490, 138]]<|/det|> A stand and spring have been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 152, 261, 167]]<|/det|> Refer to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 181, 686, 199]]<|/det|> (a) Suspend a mass \(m=100 \mathrm{~g}\) from the spring as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 215, 642, 435]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 454, 532, 471]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 486, 918, 502]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring, as indicated in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 515, 791, 532]]<|/det|> Repeat this step for values of \(m=200 \mathrm{~g}, m=300 \mathrm{~g}, m=400 \mathrm{~g}\) and \(m=500 \mathrm{~g}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 546, 465, 563]]<|/det|> Remove the mass \(m\) from the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 577, 540, 592]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 607, 603, 751]]<|/det|>
\(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{g}\)
\(l / \mathrm{cm}\)
100
200
300
400
500

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Describe a technique you used when measuring the length of the spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 320, 570, 338]]<|/det|>
(c) Plot a graph of \(l / \mathrm{cm}\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(m / g\) ( \(x\)-axis). Start the axes from the origin \((0,0)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 367, 716, 384]]<|/det|>
Draw a best-fit straight line. The line might not go through the origin.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[204, 400, 808, 829]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 880, 747, 899]]<|/det|>
(d) Use the graph to determine the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring with no load on it.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 911, 588, 934]]<|/det|>
\[
l_{0}=
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 813, 91]]<|/det|> 2 In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of insulation on the cooling of water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 261, 122]]<|/det|> Refer to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 611, 151]]<|/det|> Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 567, 181]]<|/det|> Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 200, 915, 361]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 378, 532, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 408, 529, 426]]<|/det|> (a) - Pour \(200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of hot water into beaker A. - Place the thermometer in the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 441, 918, 457]]<|/det|> - In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t=0\) and immediately start the stop-watch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 472, 918, 487]]<|/det|> - Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t=30 \mathrm{~s}, t=60 \mathrm{~s}, t=90 \mathrm{~s}\), \(t=120 \mathrm{~s}, t=150 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t=180 \mathrm{~s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 517, 509, 532]]<|/det|> Remove the thermometer from the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 548, 498, 565]]<|/det|> (b) Repeat the procedure in (a) for beaker B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 579, 540, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[189, 608, 811, 825]]<|/det|>
beaker A with insulation
beaker B without insulation
\(t / \mathrm{s}\)
\(\theta /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
\(\theta /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
0
30
60
90
120
150
180
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[330, 616, 526, 629]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[233, 638, 264, 653]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 662, 264, 677]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[234, 686, 264, 701]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[234, 711, 264, 725]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[234, 736, 264, 750]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 760, 264, 774]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 785, 264, 799]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 810, 264, 824]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by referring to values from your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 244, 918, 262]]<|/det|>
(d) (i) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker \(B\). Use your readings for beaker \(B\) from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[441, 287, 556, 321]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{1}=\frac{\theta_{0}-\theta_{90}}{T},
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 330, 918, 350]]<|/det|>
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t=0\) and \(t=90 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 377, 330, 392]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 455, 588, 474]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{1}=
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[894, 454, 919, 473]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 486, 918, 503]]<|/det|>
(ii) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[436, 529, 562, 563]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{2}=\frac{\theta_{90}-\theta_{180}}{T}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[194, 572, 918, 590]]<|/det|>
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t=180 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 618, 330, 633]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 696, 590, 716]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{2}=
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[894, 695, 919, 714]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 726, 918, 743]]<|/det|>
(e) A student suggests that, for this type of experiment, the temperature of the water in each beaker at time \(t=0\) must be the same for the comparison to be fair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 772, 785, 790]]<|/det|>
Use your answers from (d)(i) and (d)(ii) to explain whether this is necessary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(f) (i) A student wants to eliminate, from the comparison, any thermal energy lost from the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 121, 639, 138]]<|/det|>
Suggest a change to the equipment which will do that.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 152, 686, 167]]<|/det|>
You are not required to carry out this additional experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 244, 921, 261]]<|/det|>
(ii) Suggest what effect this change will have on the cooling rates of the water in beaker A and beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 796, 91]]<|/det|>
3 In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 472, 122]]<|/det|>
Use the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 149, 816, 620]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 638, 532, 653]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 667, 796, 684]]<|/det|>
(a) Place the transparent block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet. Carefully draw round the block and label the corners \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) as indicated by Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 698, 515, 715]]<|/det|>
Remove the block from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 729, 581, 747]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{A B}\) at a point \(\mathbf{N}, 2 \mathrm{~cm}\) from \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 761, 886, 778]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{E N}\), as indicated by Fig. 3.1, 8 cm long and an angle \(\theta=40^{\circ}\) to the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 616, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Replace the block in exactly the same position as in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 105, 866, 122]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{E N}\), a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 151, 918, 168]]<|/det|>
View the images of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) through the block, from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) so that pins \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 183, 482, 198]]<|/det|>
all appear exactly one behind the other. Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 228, 590, 245]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and pins from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 259, 683, 278]]<|/det|>
Draw a line through \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\). Extend this line to meet line \(\mathbf{C D}\). Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{C D}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{F}\). Label the lower end of this line

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 290, 294, 305]]<|/det|>
with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 321, 590, 337]]<|/det|>
Extend line \(\mathbf{E N}\) to approximately 5 cm below line \(\mathbf{C D}\). Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{C D}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\). Label the lower end of this line

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 351, 291, 366]]<|/det|>
with the letter \(\mathbf{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 398, 642, 415]]<|/det|>
(c) (i) Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between lines \(\mathbf{C D}\) and \(\mathbf{G F}\). An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 543, 686, 560]]<|/det|>
(ii) A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to angle \(\beta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 583, 918, 598]]<|/det|>
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 630, 283, 643]]<|/det|>
statement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 661, 291, 676]]<|/det|>
justification

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 737, 918, 754]]<|/det|>
(d) Draw a new line EN, as indicated by Fig. 3.1, 8 cm long and at an angle \(\theta=20^{\circ}\) to the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 769, 355, 785]]<|/det|>
Repeat the steps in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 846, 91]]<|/det|>
(e) Describe one technique to use in this type of experiment to ensure accurate results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 918, 184]]<|/det|>
(f) Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 504, 91]]<|/det|>
4 A student investigates the resistance of a wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables the student to investigate how the length of a wire affects the resistance of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 142, 550, 173]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation: \(R=\frac{V}{I}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 181, 834, 199]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 213, 471, 230]]<|/det|>
You are not required to do the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 244, 399, 261]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 319, 290]]<|/det|>
- a selection of wires - a variable power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 306, 261, 321]]<|/det|>
- an ammeter - a voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 351, 225, 368]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 457, 399]]<|/det|>
- list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 413, 918, 430]]<|/det|>
- complete Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
- explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 505, 487, 524]]<|/det|>
- state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 536, 918, 553]]<|/det|>
- draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 583, 606, 600]]<|/det|>
- explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 611, 667, 819]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 866, 532, 883]]<|/det|>
